content: To use for anything they want ... say weightlifting/powerlifting ... or playing chess. Could an athlete balance the requirements of time and nutrition of the sport with the military lifestyle ? (I suppose the toughest to deal would be a deployment scenario ?) Say can you time-manage at least two hours a day for the gym ? (Aside from the morning PT) ... or two hours to relax playing a video game for that matter. How much time on average ? title: How much average personal time does a soldier get ?

title: How much average personal time does a soldier get ?

content: Did a lot of lifting before I went in the service and after, but almost none during. For one thing, being "bulked up" causes some real problems for uniform requirements (20 inch neck and 30 inch thighs = uniforms like tents). Another thing is the PT and hiking requirements of the job. You got to jog/lug yourself around as well as all yer kit. Being bulked up is a real burden. I went in the Army at 5'8" 190, came out 6 years later 158. Bulked back up to 220 after getting out, then went back in Air Force and fought the nightmare of height/weight requirements for 16 years, despite remaining about 5-8% body fat. Bottom Line: It's the military mission that must matter, not your combined Max. Mine was 1300 pounds (Bench Press, Squat, and Deadlift) and it never did me any good, except maybe when humping tank ammo, fixing a road wheel, or changing a track - - Wandering and Wondering
reply: Did a lot of lifting before I went in the service and after, but almost none during. For one thing, being "bulked up" causes some real problems for uniform requirements (20 inch neck and 30 inch thighs = uniforms like tents). Another thing is the PT and hiking requirements of the job. You got to jog/lug yourself around as well as all yer kit. Being bulked up is a real burden. I went in the Army at 5'8" 190, came out 6 years later 158. Bulked back up to 220 after getting out, then went back in Air Force and fought the nightmare of height/weight requirements for 16 years, despite remaining about 5-8% body fat. Bottom Line: It's the military mission that must matter, not your combined Max. Mine was 1300 pounds (Bench Press, Squat, and Deadlift) and it never did me any good, except maybe when humping tank ammo, fixing a road wheel, or changing a track - - Wandering and Wondering

content: quote: Originally posted by m551sheridan: well pal, you have your off duty hours to hit the gym...... oh ... you *do* have off hours ? I have been conditioned to imagine that army life is 04:30am - 20:30pm seven days a week with one hour for dinner and 7hr sleep (sleep being an optional luxury, since they can make you go 24/7 if need be). In any case I just don't know what to expect; military life being so different than civilian.
quote: Originally posted by m551sheridan: well pal, you have your off duty hours to hit the gym......
reply: oh ... you *do* have off hours ? I have been conditioned to imagine that army life is 04:30am - 20:30pm seven days a week with one hour for dinner and 7hr sleep (sleep being an optional luxury, since they can make you go 24/7 if need be). title: How much average personal time does a soldier get ?

content: quote: Originally posted by ThomasAn: quote: Originally posted by m551sheridan: well pal, you have your off duty hours to hit the gym...... oh ... you *do* have off hours ? I have been conditioned to imagine that army life is 4:30am - 20:30pm with one hour for dinner and 7hr sleep (optional, since they can make 24/7 if need be). In any case I just don't what to expect. Thomas, military bases are just like the town you live in..kinda. they have shooting ranges, golf courses, tennis courts, swimming pools, shopping stores, it's almost a "you name it". At Ft. Bragg we had a guy who tried out for the post boxing team.... he made it and THAT became his job.. he had special diet, did not have to play on the tanks and he had different hours then us.... he did the boxing thing. One Flag......One Heart......One Nation............EVERMORE

title: How much average personal time does a soldier get ?

content: quote: Originally posted by ThomasAn: Thanks for your comments Ben. I am more into bodyweight and endurance training for gymnastic or MMA type performances. My main question / concern is more about being able to time-manage at least two hours a day for the gym. (not so much about practicality or usefulness). So is it possible time-wise ? ... is it possible to set aside 2 clean hours/day ? If you're single and you've got time off, Uncle Sam would rather have you staying in shape than tipping beers, that's for sure. Most posts/bases have gyms with some kind of workout facilities and weights, be they universal gyms, Nautilus, or free weights. The farther you get from civilization, the more primitive things are, of course. Also, the more primitive it gets, the more worried you are about getting a bite to eat, keeping you gear/weapon/vehicle squared away, and getting some shut-eye while you've got a chance. Energy you burn working out might be better used beating the trail or keeping alert - - Wandering and Wondering

The farther you get from civilization, the more primitive things are, of course. Also, the more primitive it gets, the more worried you are about getting a bite to eat, keeping you gear/weapon/vehicle squared away, and getting some shut-eye while you've got a chance. quote: My main question / concern is more about being able to time-manage at least two hours a day
reply: I had one of those one time. I think it was right after I made E7 back in 1966. But, they made me squeeze it into 45 minutes. I truly think every soldier should have at least one in their career. God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans
title: How much average personal time does a soldier get ?

content: quote: Originally posted by ThomasAn: Thanks for your comments Ben. I am more into bodyweight and endurance training for gymnastic or MMA type performances. My main question / concern is more about being able to time-manage at least two hours a day for the gym. (not so much about practicality or usefulness). So is it possible time-wise ? ... is it possible to set aside 2 clean hours/day ? If you're single and you've got time off, Uncle Sam would rather have you staying in shape than tipping beers, that's for sure. Most posts/bases have gyms with some kind of workout facilities and weights, be they universal gyms, Nautilus, or free weights. The farther you get from civilization, the more primitive things are, of course. Also, the more primitive it gets, the more worried you are about getting a bite to eat, keeping you gear/weapon/vehicle squared away, and getting some shut-eye while you've got a chance. Energy you burn working out might be better used beating the trail or keeping alert - - Wandering and Wondering

The farther you get from civilization, the more primitive things are, of course. content: quote: Originally posted by ThomasAn: Thanks for your comments Ben. I am more into bodyweight and endurance training for gymnastic or MMA type performances. My main question / concern is more about being able to time-manage at least two hours a day for the gym. (not so much about practicality or usefulness). So is it possible time-wise ? ... is it possible to set aside 2 clean hours/day ? It's possible, depending on the type of duty you have. I did it for most of my career, and have carried on into my retirement. It's paid off. Me today at 51.
